reviews.text:
Affordable Prices, Mixed Feelings on the Food
The prices here are definitely budget-friendly, and the portions were just right for two people.

Here‚Äôs what we tried:
-Spicy & Sour Shredded Potatoes
Unfortunately, it lacked both the sourness and the spiciness you‚Äôd expect from this dish. However, the shredded potatoes were crisp and refreshing, which was a plus.

-Country-Style Stir-Fried Pork
This dish had a nice wok aroma and tender pork, but it was very oily. The green peppers were soaked in oil, making it a bit heavy. That said, it paired well with rice.

-Boiled Sliced Pork in Spicy Soup
The soup and meat were both quite salty. While the portion was generous and the pork tender, the overpowering saltiness made it hard to enjoy fully. It included bean sprouts, black ear mushrooms, enoki mushrooms, and pork slices.

-Garlic Pork Slices
At this price, I wasn‚Äôt expecting a lot of meat, but the presentation was a bit misleading. Only 7‚Äì8 thin slices of pork were laid over a bed of cucumber, giving the illusion of a full bowl. The cucumber had absorbed a lot of chili oil, which made it less refreshing than expected.

-Grilled Sausage
This was decent. It was juicy and flavorful, though be careful when biting into it‚Äîas it can be quite hot inside.

-White Rice
Surprisingly, this was my favorite. The rice was sticky and had a nice texture. We saw others helping themselves to refills the rice and were told it was free, we even double confirm with the staff is the rice for free refill and the staff replied us Ya/Yes. But we were charged in the end. It wasn‚Äôt a big deal, but a bit confusing.

Overall for me, I think that If you‚Äôre curious to try something new or looking for Chinese food on a budget, this place is okay.
But for me, it‚Äôs a one-time visit. The food didn‚Äôt quite meet my expectations, but the price point may make it worthwhile for others.

Nestled in Eco botanic, Small Reunion Restaurant is a delightful surprise for lovers of regional Chinese cuisine. Specializing in Dong Bei, Sichuan, and Hunan dishes, this week-old gem already shines with its comforting ‚Äúhome-cooked‚Äù ethos and warm, attentive service.

The menu is a flavorful tour of China‚Äôs diverse culinary regions. The claypot presentation isn‚Äôt just aesthetic; it locks in heat and aroma, making every bite feel like it‚Äôs straight from a family kitchen. True to their promise, flavors are rustic, hearty, and unmistakably authentic‚Äîno fussy twists, just honest, satisfying cooking.

What elevates the meal is the genuinely friendly service. The staff (and possibly the owners) greet diners with enthusiasm, happily explaining dishes or recommending personal favorites. Their pride in the food is palpable, and the welcoming vibe makes you feel like a guest at a lively family gathering.

Price-wise, it‚Äôs a win. For a restaurant barely a week old, Small Reunion already feels like a neighborhood staple. If you‚Äôre craving regional Chinese flavors served with warmth and authenticity, this spot is worth seeking out. A delicious reminder that sometimes, the best meals do taste like home. ü•¢üç≤

Most dishes are good. But Guo Bao Rou (one of the most expensive in the menu) is disappointing. The pieces are small, more flour than meat and not easy to chew.

We asked specifically no chili because there are children. But they still put chili üò≥
Your simple China dishes serve in clay pots. Lovely calrose rice to pair with tasty dishes. Hit the spot and reasonably priced
The food was good and the environment was clean and bright. You can bring your friends or family for dinner. Downside was the parking is difficult to find here.

vicinity: 35, Jalan Eko Botani 3/4, 79100 Gelang Patah, Johor Bahru
